content: The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, citing the Civil Rights movement as a prime example of this principle in action. Key events such as the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, drive for voting rights in Mississippi, and March to Selma are highlighted. The Civil Rights movement included key events like the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, drive for voting rights in Mississippi, and March to Selma. While well-known leaders like Thurgood Marshall, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and Rosa Parks played significant roles, there were many other important participants whose stories and memories provide a rich history of the movement. A project to collect oral histories of individuals from the Civil Rights movement will provide a detailed history for future generations. This effort aims to preserve primary-source material and highlight the various entities working on interpreting articles related to the movement. The purpose of this Act is to create a federally sponsored project to collect and interpret oral histories related to the Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution will serve as repositories for these oral histories, utilizing their expertise in documentation management and cultural programs. The Act aims to establish a federally sponsored project to collect personal histories and testimonials of individuals involved in the American Civil Rights movement. The project will coordinate the collection of video and audio recordings at a national level, complementing previous documentary work. The goal is to preserve these memories for future generations to better understand the sacrifices made. The Act establishes a joint project at the Library of Congress and National Museum of African American History and Culture to collect video and audio recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights Movement. The project aims to preserve personal histories for future generations to understand the sacrifices made. The Secretary will establish an oral history project to survey and collect audio and video recordings of participants in the Civil Rights movement to avoid duplication of efforts and preserve personal histories. The Secretary will establish an oral history project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories and materials related to individuals in the Civil Rights movement for public use. The Librarian and the Secretary will make the collection available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary's duties under this Act will be carried out through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Librarian and the Secretary may also collaborate with other entities for carrying out activities. The Librarian and the Secretary may collaborate with other entities through agreements and partnerships to carry out activities for making recordings available under the project. They can also consult with interested persons and develop guidelines for acquiring recordings. Additionally, they can utilize the services of experts and consultants in advance payments for these activities. In carrying out activities for making recordings available, the Librarian and the Secretary can procure services, accept volunteers, and make advance payments in accordance with relevant codes. The Librarian and the Secretary will start collecting video and audio recordings related to the Civil Rights movement as soon as possible after the enactment of the Act, focusing on the period 1954 through 1968. The term "Civil Rights movement" refers to the movement for racial equality in the United States for African Americans, challenging racial segregation. The Civil Rights movement, focusing on the period 1954 through 1968, challenged racial segregation and achieved equal rights legislation for all American citizens. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary are encouraged to solicit donations to support activities related to Civil Rights history. The Librarian of Congress can receive funds to support activities under section 3, which must be deposited into a dedicated account and used solely for those activities. The Librarian cannot deposit funds not intended for this purpose. $500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010 to carry out this Act. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $500,000 for fiscal year 2010 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2011 through 2014.
